results.title: The Global environment
results.brief_description: From acid rain to the greenhouse effect, from rainforests to desertification… this highly acclaimed series brings together the major world environmental issues and presents them in a form that is both accessible and easy to use. The ten, 20 minute programmes examine themes such as - the limited nature of our global resources, the interdependence of human life and the physical environment, the necessity of a sustainable basis for development. Underlying this is a central message - that an understanding of these themes is crucial if our planet is to survive. The video comes with notes for teachers offering an outline of each programme and useful resources for follow-up work. The ten parts are: 1 - ‘In the shadow of the city’: urbanisation. 2 - ‘Breaking Ground’: Soil erosion and desertification. 3 - ‘What’s on tap’: water pollution. 4 - ‘Timber!’: forest management. 5 - ‘The Greenhouse Effect’: global warming and possible effects. 6 - ‘Power for the people’: energy conservation. 7 - ‘A Breath of fresh air’: air pollution and acid rain. 8 - ‘Down in the dumps’: waste and waste recycling. 9 - ‘The Troubled sea’: overfishing and ocean pollution. 10 - ‘Our future world’: round-up of the series. Suitable for years 7-10.

results.title: Screening Middlemarch: [19th. century] novel to 90's TV
results.brief_description: Takes the student and the teacher behind the scenes to offer fascinating insights into the complex task of bringing a great 19th Century novel to the television screen. It uses authentic materials from different aspects of the TV and radio production process. It gives opportunities to compare George Eliot’s original text with the radio adaptation, the TV production and the screenwriter’s version, by using excerpts from the actual dramatisation. Allows both teachers and students the opportunity to re-edit some of the shots taken by the production team, and to compare their versions with the broadcast version. It examines the roles of sound effects and music in relation to narrative and realism. This programme will not only teach the process of turning a book into a television serial, but by examining such concepts as narrative, realism, character, gender, class and the use of the authorial voice, will also help students with the study of the novel generally. The kit contains one 90 minute videocassette, one 60 minute audiocassette and one comprehensive activity book.

results.title: The Camel boy
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: In Australia’s early days the ship of the desert, the camel, was imported to help explore the harsh interior of this vast continent. Through the wonder of animation and live action ‘The Camel Boy’ takes you back to the beginning of this century for an exciting adventure story based on the actual journeys of explorers in Australia’s outback wilderness. The burning sands of the inland desert and the hurricane lashed waters of the ocean are the setting for this story of friendship between a boy and a camel.

results.title: P.G-H: a modern odyssey
results.creator_credit: I. James Wilson, John Tristram, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: The life and times of the Australian born composer, Peggy Glanville-Hicks, also known as PG-H, who lived and worked in America with world renowned writers, musicians and choreographers. She became a distinguished music critic for the Hreald Tribune. Her compositions include concertos, sonatas and works for the theatre.

results.title: Pain, passion and profit
results.creator_credit: Gurinder Chadha, Gerard Rosenberg, BBC and International Broadcasting Trust
results.brief_description: Anita Roddick, founder and manager of Body Shop International visits Africa and looks at how women entrepreurs survive and flourish. In Kenya she investigates a successful women’s cooperative producing an efficient earthenware stove and in Ghana she looks at a food preservation business and a clothing industry, both managed by women.

results.title: The 12 steps: recovering from addictions. - Steps Nine to Thirteen.
results.creator_credit: Jim Hanley, Sleeping Giant Productions, Kaleidoscope Entertainment and Manitoba TV
results.brief_description: The 12 characters introduced in episodes one to eight continue relating their experiences of the Alcoholics Anonymous 12 step program. Step 9. “Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others.” 10. “Continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted to it.” 11. “Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with God as we understood him, praying only for knowledge of his will and the power to carry that out.” 12. “Having had a spiritual awakening as a result of these steps, we tried to carry this message to addicts, and to practice these principles in all our affairs.” 13. “Relapse.” Narrated by John Vernon.

results.title: The 12 steps: recovering from addictions. - Steps One to Eight.
results.creator_credit: Jim Hanley, Sleeping Giant Productions, Kaleidoscope Entertainment and Manitoba TV
results.brief_description: Throughout the 13 episodes, 12 characters are constantly entwined. Their experiences of the Alcoholics Anonymous 12 step program, compellingly told and captured first hand are interspersed with expert opinion for structural cohesiveness and direction. Step 1: “We admitted we were powerless over our addiction - that our lives had become unmanageable.” 2. “Came to believe that a Power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity”. 3. “Made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of God as we understood him.”. 4. “Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.” 5. “Admitted to ourselves and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.” 6. “Were entirely ready to have God remove all these defects of character.” 7. “Humbly asked him to remove our shortcomings.” 8. “Made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all.” Narrated by John Vernon.

results.title: Sir Jack Brabham: The complete history of a motor racing legend
results.creator_credit: Neville Hay and Hay Fisher Productions
results.brief_description: Brabham - one of the great names in motor racing history. A great driver who not only became a household name worldwide during the 1950’s and 60’s for his driving exploits, but who also created a racing team that was still winning in the 1980’s. This story of Sir Jack Brabham, told exclusively in his own words and by close associates including Stirling Moss, Roy Salvadori and and John Cooper. Extensive archival material captures the feel of some glorious motor racing while tracing every step of a truly brilliant career.

results.title: Conflict of interest (D)
results.creator_credit: Tony Wellington, Ian MacArthur and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The basis of this film is the National Park and Wildlife Services kangaroo control and management program. The kangaroo is shown, historically, as a source of food for the Aborigines, as game and a source of income for the first Europeans and today as a symbol of Australia. The Kangaroo Management Program is discussed at length. It aims to ensure the conservation of all species of macropods, the investigation of agricultural damage and the best use of product derived from culling kangaroos. Statistical information on kangaroo culling is presented diagramatically.

results.title: The Miraculous Mellops 2. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans, Film Australia and Millenium Pictures
results.brief_description: In this series of episodes, the Mellops family discover WOOPS or Windows of Opportunity; the only known way to travel faster than light. The alien grubs and their disgusting habits are planning to visit earth and Dump manages to steal the WOOP for his own purposes but runs into a few pointy obstacles. The adventures of the Mellops, Dumps and Grubs, takes us out of the plant nursery into outer space.
